statement.p: Find the point of intersection of the lines y = x + 1 and 2x+3y=14\text{.}

image.description: a graph with axes depicting two intersecting lines

statement.p: The point of intersection is (x,y) where x= and y=.
The solution of the linear system
is
x= and y=

Suppose a jar contains red, blue and green marbles. You are told that there are a total of {48} marbles in the jar; there are twice as many red marbles as green ones; the number of blue marbles is the same as the sum of the red and green marbles. How many marbles of each color are there?
Solve the system:
Solve the system:
Use the method of elimination to solve the linear system:
The solution is x= and y=.
Use the method of elimination to solve the linear system:
The solution is x_1=, x_2= and x_3=.
Write the augmented matrix of the system
Write the augmented matrix of the system

li.p: Which of the following correctly describes the matrix above?
The matrix is 3\times 5, with 3 rows and 5 columns.
The matrix is 5\times 3, with 5 rows and 3 columns.
The matrix is 5\times 3, with 5 columns and 3 rows.
The matrix is 3\times 5, with 3 columns and 5 rows.
Now consider an {3} \times {9} matrix B\text{.} If B is an augmented matrix, the corresponding linear system has how many variables?

(a) The initial matrix is:
(b) First, perform the Row Operation \frac{1}{3} R_1 \to R_1. The resulting matrix is:
(c) Next, perform the operation -5 R_1 + R_2 \to R_2. The resulting matrix is:
(d) Finish simplifying the augmented matrix. The reduced matrix is:
(e) What are the solutions to the system?
Reduce the matrix A= \left[\begin{array}{cccc} -3 \amp -6 \amp -3 \amp -24\cr 0 \amp -4 \amp -6 \amp -20\cr 0 \amp -8 \amp -16 \amp -48 \end{array}\right] to reduced row-echelon form.

hint.p: First, do \frac{1}{-3} R_1 \to R_1, resulting in \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 8\cr 0 \amp -4 \amp -6 \amp -20\cr 0 \amp -8 \amp -16 \amp -48 \end{array}\right]

Then, do \frac{1}{-4} R_2 \to R_2, resulting in \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 8\cr 0 \amp 1 \amp 1.5 \amp 5\cr 0 \amp -8 \amp -16 \amp -48 \end{array}\right] Next, do 8 R_2+R_3 \to R_3, resulting in \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 \amp 2 \amp 1 \amp 8\cr 0 \amp 1 \amp 1.5 \amp 5\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp -4 \amp -8 \end{array}\right]
Now we can multiply R_3 by a constant to create the leading 1, and then do the backwards steps.

statement.p: Reduce the matrix A= \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 3 \amp -3 \amp 4 \amp -15\cr -1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 2\cr 3 \amp 3 \amp -2 \amp 3 \end{array}\right] to reduced row-echelon form.
The reduced row-echelon forms of the augmented matrices of four systems are given below. How many solutions does each system have?
How many free variables does each augmented matrix have?
How many determined (basic) variables does each augmented matrix have?
Convert the system

p.me: \begin{array}{rcrcrcr}-4 x_1 \amp - \amp 7 x_{2} \amp = \amp 2 \\4 x_1 \amp + \amp 9 x_{2} \amp = \amp -6 \\ x_1 \amp + \amp 2 x_{2} \amp = \amp -1\end{array}

statement.p: to an augmented matrix. Then reduce the system to echelon form and determine if the system is consistent.
Augmented matrix:
Echelon form:

Is the system consistent?
select
yes
no

p.m: \begin{array}{ccc} \left[\begin{array}{rrr} -4 \amp -7 \amp 2 \\ 4 \amp 9 \amp -6 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp -1\end{array}\right] \amp \overset{R_1 \Leftrightarrow R_3}{\sim} \amp \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 4 \amp 9 \amp -6 \\ -4 \amp -7 \amp 2\end{array}\right] \\ \amp \overset{\begin{align*}-4 R_1 + R_2 \amp \Rightarrow R_2 \\ 4 R_1 + R_3 \amp \Rightarrow R_3\end{align*}}{\sim} \amp \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -2\end{array}\right] \\ \amp \overset{- R_2 + R_3 \Rightarrow R_3}{\sim} \amp \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 2 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0\end{array}\right] \end{array}

statement.p: Solve the system by finding the reduced row-echelon form of the augmented matrix. \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} x+ y+ 3 z \amp = -5 \\ 2 x+ 3 y+ 7 z \amp = -6 \\ -3 x- y - 7 z \amp = 23 \end{array}\right.
reduced row-echelon form:
How many solutions are there to this system?
If there is one solution, give its coordinates in the answer spaces below.

If there are infinitely many solutions, enter z in the answer blank for z, enter a formula for y in terms of z in the answer blank for y and enter a formula for x in terms of z in the answer blank for x.
If there are no solutions, leave the answer blanks for x, y and z empty.
Enter two numbers that are equal, and the first one must be a 2: =
